You floated around different parts of California working for the Panthers.
I won't say - floated is the wrong word - but intentionally moved around to different headquarters.
Los Angeles was known in Panther lore as the Red Zone.
There were constant shootouts with the police, and 11 Panthers, one-fourth of all Panther fatalities from 1966 to 1977, died here.
Explain to us what Los Angeles was like when you worked there for the Panthers, and what you were doing specifically?
I guess it was the closest thing that you may experience in this country to being in a combat zone.
We had to reinforce our offices; they were sandbagged.
And one of our major functions there is we were organizing.

We did that mainly through selling the Black Panther newspaper and organizing dozens of free breakfast programs for school children, and basically organizing young African-Americans around the issues of self-defense.

Now when you talk about self-defense, you were dealing with the legalities of owning guns, marching with guns and dealing with laws that were not put on the books necessarily for black people, which made it very controversial for the Panthers to do what they did.
What made you think you could get away with this?
You know, I don't think it was a matter of getting away with it.
I think it was a matter of survival.
You know, putting myself into context of that particular period, and I really believe that, you know, my survival depended on me being able to defend myself in this country.
I'm going to jump ahead in your story a little bit.
You were shot and wounded and tried to escape.
Tell us about the circumstances of that day.
That was in October 1977, and I was involved with the military arm of the organization and had been for about six years.
I concocted a plot to kill a witness.
The witness was testifying against Huey Newton, who had just recently returned from Cuba, where he had been in exile for about three years.
And we had a plan to kill the witness the morning of his preliminary hearing, and the operation got botched.
And I was wounded, another Panther was killed.
And from that point on I became a fugitive, of which I was for the next three years.
And then what happened?
Well, I was a fugitive for three years.
I turned myself in and I was convicted of felony murder.
And I went to prison in California, and I served four years, eight months and nine days in the California Department of Corrections.
Who were you as a man when you walked into prison and did it change by the time you walked out?
When I got to prison I guess I was somewhat of a celebrity.
Many of the people in prison knew of me from the streets of California.
Ironically, when I got to Soledad I ran into almost my entire neighborhood.
People I had grown up with, played Little League baseball with, Pop Warner football with, went to church with, and they were also incarcerated.
But when I, you know, I guess when I got there I was still a combatant, I was an urban guerilla.

And I was probably thinking about changing my life but when I, as soon as I walked into prison I realized that I was going to have to keep the same demeanor and behavior that I had when I was on the street.
So what did the Panther movement accomplish in terms of considering violence or considering weapons as a tool of liberation?
Did it make a difference?
I don't think it was the theater of the gun, because there was no way that we would win a shooting war in this country.
I think that the difference came about through the survivor programs that the Black Panther Party created.
I mean today you still have free breakfast programs for schoolchildren.
You have free lunch programs; you have free health clinics.
In some ways it seems to me that you're saying that the bread was more powerful than the bullet in what the legacy of the Panthers is.
And you now are a strategic officer of the Abyssinian Development Corporation in New York City, this organization that is really trying to work and transform Harlem.
I just wonder a couple of things.
One, do you ever regret being involved in trying to murder someone?
And two, does your work now flow directly out of what you did during the years as a Panther?
No, I don't regret anything that I did.
That was my nature then.
You know, I'm not going to be that remorseful.
It's unfortunate that some of my friends were killed.
That's the only thing I actually regret.
Today, you know - well, you know, at one time we believed, you know, the organization was not going to last but the struggle was going to continue.
So what form and shape would it take?
And I think that you have a lot of people who were in the Black Panther Party who are involved in legislative practice.
You have people who are urban planners, like myself, who are involved in community development.
And a lot of the issues that we are promoting are very similar to the issues that were in the Black Panther Party's 10-Point Platform and Program.
Flores Forbes, thank you so much.
Thank you.
Flores Forbes is the author of Will You Die With Me?: My Life and the Black Panther Party.

Laugh-In,"" just to remind people - a very, very popular, highly rated show back in the '60s and...
With short sketches.

And that seemed to suit what we thought was the short attention span of children, that there would be these short segments, these bursts, and then what we called commercials, which were little spots to teach letters and numbers that were threaded through the hour, as if they were commercials, because children were used to commercial interruption.
Where we were wrong, I think, and we were ill-advised, was telling us that two, threes and fours can't follow plot.
And of course, that turned about to be totally wrong, and we do much more plot now on ""Sesame Street."" The segments are not nearly as short as they were in the beginning.

But at the beginning, though, you did something that would have been very unusual for - certainly for children's TV at that time; you put it in a distinct urban environment, and I mean, just things like Oscar the Crouch, coming out of a garbage can.
Yeah, it was pretty, cutting edge, let us say.
We decided not to have it in some magic house, you know, the way most children's programs are set, in a fantasy setting of some kind, or in the suburbs, as ""Mister Rogers' Neighborhood"" was.
And we were trying to reach all children, but the bull's-eye of the target, as we used to say, were intercity youngsters.
Obviously, city children were watching all these shows set in the suburbs, though it was not their experience.
So, children can move very fast between reality and fantasy, and it need not be their experience, because if you stop and think about it, very little is of their experience.
There're only two, three and four years old.
So, they're far more accepting of different things.

When you were a three year old yourself, or a four year old yourself, in Phoenix, Arizona, and that was back in the 1930s, what was the nearest thing that you had, if there was anything at all near to it, to ""Sesame Street""?
Well, there was nothing near to ""Sesame Street."" I used to listen - I don't think I listened to radio as a three year old.
By four or five, my parents took me to movies with them.
The only time one saw cartoons were at - when one went to the movies on Saturday morning.
There would be cartoons before the feature.
So, there was nothing comparable.
Education was not a big deal for children.
I did not even go to kindergarten; I just started first grade when I was five and started reading right away.
I don't know how it all worked, but I had a lot of adults and older siblings around me.
So, I guess I was probably introduced to what one would be introduced to at that time in kindergarten.
When you first started ""Sesame Street,"" or first got to thinking about it, were there moments when you were just inspired?
People today would think, oh, Jim Henson walked in with ""The Muppets."" Was that a moment of revelation, or did you not know what you had at the time?
Oh, I knew; we knew.
I had seen his work doing commercials.
Inside the business ,it was known he was a genius.
And I remember one of the producers said, let's try to get Jim Henson.
And I said, you think we could get him?
We would not be around now, if we weren't self-supporting and that it was Jim Henson's Muppets that made us self-supporting.
They became instant parts of the - you know...
Yes, they were instant stars; there is no question.
Big Bird was the biggest star, I mean, children's favorite for a number of years.
I have a 22-year-old granddaughter whose first words were Big Bird.
Nowadays, the first word is Elmo, but that - Elmo is almost doubtless the most popular children's character, probably in the world, but certainly in the Western world.
When you started, there was a fair amount of skepticism about children's television being both fun and also educational...
Yes.
Even among some teachers at the time, but you're still looking ahead, right?
Digital media, Internet, videogames, things that sell songs...
Yes.
Things like that?
Yes, absolutely.
We're very interested in using the new media to teach.
You don't resist it at all?
Oh, no. I've got too many grandchildren not to understand the power of the new media.
I don't know - if I didn't have grandchildren - that's an interesting question - I don't know if I would - I mean, I'd be aware that you had to go there and had to go where the kids are.
It's very tough, though, because if you think back to the late '60s and '70s and '80s, children only watched television for information or for entertainment.
Now, they've got all these media.
It's a tougher world to find a way of having impactful educational value for children.
